description: Might have good features if it was usable. The application doesn't respond to nor launch onscreen keyboard when used on a tablet and it has been that way well over a year. Goodness knows how many security vulnerabilities remain as ignored by the developers..equally
Superb application. I wish more people started using it.
Riot (and Matrix) really shines for doing modern team chat right, while also being entirely decentralized and not owned nor controlled by any outside authority.
summary: Great choice for teams or online communities

description:
Matrix is one of those technologies that you wish came along sooner.

Riot specifically is one of those applications that has really changed the game of decentralized communication. Being able to communicate without relying on large corporate infrastructure is liberating. Setting up your own matrix server is also possible and riot makes it a snap to connect to your own personal server.

I am seeing communities starting to take advantage of the new encryption which is exciting.

Oh and in case you didn't know, France is now migrating to Matrix for it's communication needs.
very good app! i never used it, but it is a FLATPAK!!
Federated chat, with FOSS server and multiple clients. Easy to use with the default matrix.org server or you can find a 3rd party server or run your own.

Been using riot for over a year now.
It's really coming along. Good time to start getting friends onboard!

I've tried all the Matrix clients and Element (previously Riot) is definitely the best in terms of featureset and usability.

It's Electron though so it's quite heavy on system resources.

In terms of functionality, Element is the gold standard for Matrix chat apps. But its UI is a bit... special. Its cross-platform UI doesn't really look or feel native anywhere, and it doesn't respect any platform UI styling such as icon theme, color scheme, light/dark, etc. If you can stand this, It will serve you well.
summary: Works well but UI is a bit weird

description: Tackling the most pressing issue of our day Matrix/Element is returning power to individuals.

was using manjaro KDE now fedora KDE fresh install and still crashing outta nowhere, oof, now i know it's a element-desktop problem

yeah confirmed absolutely crashing even when i'm typing sometimes game breaker
summary: laggy and crashes even on fresh distro install

description: Crashing on fresh Nobara Fedora spin.
Ive installed element over discover app store and it works for a few minutes, then it closes itself without any error message. Please fix it, i love element!

It allows me to send 1 message, but only if do it fast enough, otherwise it just force closes after 5 - 10 seconds and can't stay open.
I tried using this command to open it:
"flatpak run im.riot.Riot --enable-features=UseOzonePlatform,WebRTCPipeWireCapturer --ozone-platform=wayland" and it seems to remain open.
It's cool that there is a CLI alternative to make it run correctly, but it sucks that this would push new Linux users on Wayland to think Linux is a broken system.
Hopefully this will be fixed soon enough. If it works with that command, I see no reason why it cannot be modified to just work as intended.
Bottom line is, it works, after some tweaking.
Element's pretty alright however trying to use this Flatpak on the Steam Deck is near enough not possible - it crashes about a minute after launch every time.
It crashes everytime under 10 seconds. I can't use it. I use openSUSE Thumbleweed, KDE desktop.
Awful implementation of the app. It crashes constantly and will automatically log you out of your server and login which is a pain if you have encryption keys.

It will constantly, consistantly, and for no reason, crash within a minute of launch.

It is quite literally unusable, and has been for months. I don't know what started it; it used to work fine. Now its like this, but clearly from other reviews I am not alone.
Worthless. Crashes all the time. I can't even use this. I'll be installing chromium and using my web server edition in a PWA. At least then I can actually use this program

Very nice way to install an app. But this app is not maintained by the official developers. I thought Flatpaks were supposed to give users direct access to the releases done by the developers themselves. At least, that's how it's advertised, and it's not true (in this case).

The general UI layout looks kinda like Discord, but that's where the similarity ends. There is quite a learning curve, I'm still trying to figure out how to add rooms to a community. (rooms=channels, communities=servers, though that's an over simplification)
summary: Closest thing the FOSS world has to Discord

description:
I cannot login on an instance that works on web, and it doesn't show errors.
Also what is the purpose of this, when I can just use a webapp? I expected something much lighter and written natively.
summary: just a webapp, cannot set up

description:
Element is a very feature rich client. And by itself an amazing well working communication solution which already has features that are missing in other solutions. 
The most important part for me is that it is running on the matrix protocol which makes it very versitile and future prove.
summary: Matrix is a really good communication solution

description: Provides a user interface that is simply pleasing to look at; far better than Discord and other communication applications. The widgets are a nice touch for a business/industrial work (Especially the Etherpad and Jitsi) for having meetings and keeping track on what needs to get done all in on place. Best of all, the video/voice quality is far superb in comparison to the other applications in its class. Wanna know what else? ENCRYPTION! Finally something that's secure and open source especially to its users. Overall a great experience!
summary: Simple, Intuitive, Secure, Modern, and overall great experience

description: Nothing to add.
summary: All the best features from RiotX and Riot.im

description: Great chat app, getting better every week.
summary: Best video and audio quality than Whatsapp!

description: Matrix and in extent element are by far the best chat service I have used compared to others such as discord it may lack some features but it is mostly comparable and it has respect for privacy and allows you to use any client not just element.
summary: One of the best chat apps

description: Everything works fine so far. Very cool is the E2EE encryption. I can just transfer my keys between different devices with just some clicks!
summary: Easy to use and secure E2EE

description: love the irc bridges =)
The only sad thing is that it uses Electron. But it's still fast, just a bit weird when it comes to styluses.
Such a good alternative to all other chat applications and now with spaces it seems it could be well set to replace them
please add tor
Element has worked well for as long as I've used it, and I recommend that everyone give it a shot.
Love it, works well.

The look and feel of Element... I just don't like it. It's slow on Windows, Linux, and Android, sometimes it just doesn't work at all, messages stick to the bottom, and the constant feeling of 'Woah, that doesn't feel polished' just adds up to a bad UX in the end. I really wish this was a better client, but it has a very very long way to go.
summary: I don't think they know how to design a UX

description: especially good aspect is that it's cross-platform including a webpage!
Federated messaging is long overdue. These guys have done it right. Professional and modern interface. Very good.

Element seems to be for Android and Windows users, don't waste your time with it on Linux. It's sluggish and more than 100MB in size because it's built on the hot garbage that is electron. The bloat and sluggishness might be forgiven if it could mange to run for more than a minute without crashing, but it can't.
summary: All it does consistently is crash

description: The matrix protocol is pretty cool, but the element (basically electron wraper) is very slow and laggy. Native app is overdue.
Feels very sluggish (delay when typing etc.) Other that that it's fine.
I love Element and Matrix, but the Flatpak app from Flathub stable is not able to connect/authenticate properly, so this is unusable.
summary: Flatpak is broken for me, as of the latest update

description: simple and secure
Works great. Best Matrix client imo
Something is broken with this Flatpak and Fedora 36. Crashes a few seconds after launch. Has worked fine previously
summary: Not working since last 2 versions. Crashes on launch

description: The application itself is very nice, but it constantly crashes randomly within minutes of being opened. It makes the application totally unusable. I hope they fix this in the future because I'd love a great Element desktop application!
keeps crashing on start every time
summary: keeps crashing on start every time

description: Constantly crashes and wigs out, someimtes doesn't open again until you clear data or cache and then you have to log in again. After logging back in it just goes back to crashing. Devs were unhelpful and blamed my computer after submitting logs - Happens on every linux device I own.
Crash in Fedora 37
As soon as i start it up it crashes.

There is a massive regression where the flatpak crashes constantly under wayland. It also does the same with a native electron version but it eventually works itself out, running it with `--enable-features=UseOzonePlatform,WebRTCPipeWireCapturer --ozone-platform=wayland` seems to level the problem out some but then no window decorations. Ultimately its useless until it gets sorted out, Ill end up building it from source myself.
The app is awesome, but this packaging is just terrible.
summary: Crashes on wayland randomly and very often

description: Element's Flatpak constantly crashes, being killed by SIGTRAP. I can't even have it open for 30 seconds. It's a shame because if it wasn't for this I'd give it the full 5 stars it actually deserves.

I've already tried with the Wayland tweak and on X11 (withou the tweak) and could not use this package at all. It opens and when I try to send a message (like, after 15 after opening it) the entire application crashes.
summary: Element is constantly crashing in my system

description: On a fresh F37 workstation install, the Flatpak version crashes every few minutes, making it essentially unusable.
I like the app apart of the verification which is more then annoying and the impossibility of using it under Fedora.
summary: Max 1 minute fan tornado then crash every time same

description: Crashes straight after startup

The client is miserble and frequently takes measurable seconds to post a message, has no functional search beyond basic keywords, and ocasionally just fails to show you messages replying to you. This is excacerbated by the matrix protocol itself quite simply being immature and lacking features. E2E encryption is so unreliable that it would be a better experience to not have it.

In every negative way, mastrix is the mastodon of chat apps.

 I would rate it 0 stars if I could.
summary: This is easily one of the worst chat apps that I have ever used

description: crashes after 2 minutes. There also seems to be a noticable amount of input lag
Crashes after first login and browsing a few rooms. Keeps crashign each item I open it after that.

I have been trying many clients that works with my Matrix homeserver, but unfortunately Matrix protocol support is either spotty, or I just can't get many features to work properly. With this client, everything seems to work. 
Also, the Android version of this seems to be good, only Linux Desktop seems to crash, and the deb package throws java errors and sometimes does not even load. 
It's one of those things, it works, but using it is a bit painful, I just put up with it.
summary: It does crash, but so far is the best we have

description: Haven't used this app for long yet, but I read the reviews of constant crashing and was reminded of other apps that behaved the same for me in the past. I solved it by disabling Wayland and enabling fallback to x.11, and it worked for me on this app too, just thought I would share
Crashes and logs out all the time, does't happen on the native packages.
summary: Wonderful app but the flatpak is horrible

description: Crash crash crash crash
The Element chat app is one of the only fully-featured Matrix clients. This Flatpak used to be extremely unstable but they fixed it and it works great now.

Fedora 37 Gnome: The app crashes at times, but the broken window system is the most annoying bug. The window bar becomes large if the window is not full screen. Window bars haven't had controls (close window, etc) for the past two updates. They used to be there. Something is terribly wrong with the Gnome integration of the flatpak. Moving to the browser version has solved all problems. The flatpak has negative advantages so far.

Found that Matrix uses ~900MiB of RAM sitting in the background (with no indication that it is running).
I have a pretty new Matrix account with little conversations.

It's an Electron app... works about as well as can be expected under a KDE Plasma 5 + X11 session.

I like that this uses official tarballs from Element.io. This is the upstream Linux build repacked for Flathub.
Wish it had notification badges on Fedora.
The display resolution of this app is really low for some reason. Of all the Element apps that are out there, this is definitely the worst one I've come across.

Unfortunetly the latest update of the Element app (both Native and FlatPak) versions do not stop under computer restart on Debian 12 for me. It causes the computer to hang indefinatley (left for over an hour) stuck on "Rebooting". Once uninstalled, my machine has returned to normal operation. When ever this is fixed, I will return!
Probably best instant messaging app for security and privacy.
summary: State of art security instant messaging app

description: Some people may like that, but it drives me crazy. Time to uninstall.
summary: Pops up notifications by default even when not running

description: This is a wonderful chat app if you want secure and decentralized chats. The Flathub version of it used to be very unstable but this is not the case anymore.
summary: Great app and it improved a lot

description:
to fix drag and drop you need to install "Flatseal" for editing flatpak permissions, disable wayland setting, scroll down, enable access to user files, add whatever other folder you want it to have access too, like external drives, and it works
at least for me on nobara, with wayland setting enabled it stops regestering any mouse input after you drag the file in.

Habe die App mit beiden Paketquellen getestet (Flathub and User). Leider wird beim Start die App nicht angezeigt. Sehe nur das Trayicon unten rechts. Klicke ich dort drauf, wird mit Element in der Taskleiste angezeigt als aufgerufen, aber ich sehe es nicht. Muss dann bei der Taskleiste mit Rechtklick auf "Schließen" klicken und erneut auf das Tray Icon. Danach wird mir Element angezeigt. Komplett weirder Fehler, keine Ahnung wie ich das lösen soll. Nobara Linux Fedora 39 mit KDE Wayland.
Eine der besten Desktop-Chat-Anwendungen, die ich bislang verwendet habe. Dazu kommen dann auch noch die Vorteile von Matrix.

Very good Matrix Client for the average user. I think more advanced users will stick with some other Matrix client to improve decentralization of the software, however Element is a decent choice for everyone.
I am using this flatpak daily to communication in IRC channels and matrix rooms. I had no problems with it so far.

Element (Riot.im) ist aus meiner sicht der beste Messenger fürs Kollaboratives Arbeiten im Team, da er kostenlos, opensource und Datenschutzfreundlich ist. Die vielen Funktionen, wie Audio/Video Chat und die nützlichen Integrationen wie Jitsi, BigBlueButton, Ehtercalc erleichtern das gemeinsame Arbeiten. Meines Wissens können beliebege Integrationen von den Serveradministrationen ergänzt werden, wodurch also keine Grenzen gesetzt sind. Der einzige Hacken ist die Verbreitung unter Linux, offiziel wird nur Debian/Ubuntu angeboten, weshalb man ansonsten auf Flatpak zurückgreifen muss. Dadurch hat man zwar immer die neuste Version aber auch alle Fehler und Probleme, die Flatpak mitbringt, darum ein Stern Abzug. Die Anwendung an sich hat aber fünf Sterne verdient.
summary: Bester FOSS Messenger für Kollaboratives Arbeiten

description:
Riot.im ist eine sehr gute Chat-App, die Privatsphäre respektiert und Ende-zu-ende Verschlüsselung unterstützt.
Allerdings hat diese Anwendung nicht sehr viele Benutzer.
The application crashes at the first start. On the second start it works. (Fedora 37)
summary: Works fine, but crashes on first start under Fedora 37

description: Used to crash on first start and then run on second. Now it just crashes on every start. :| Tried on a freshly-installed-and-updated Fedora 37 and still happens.
Diese App ist nicht nutzbar. Stürzt noch 2 min ab und man muss sich wieder anmelden.
Leider ist die Anwendung so nicht benutzbar. Element stürzt auf Fedora 38 ständig ab. Das scheint ein spezifisches Problem mit dem Flatpak zu sein.
used to work well but now it crashes on every time I run it on fedora silverblue 38 . Now I have to use the browser version
Eines Tages waren im Anwendungsfenster nur noch ein paar graue Vierecke zu sehen. Außerdem wurde ich in der Vergangenheit mehrmals plötzlich aus meinem Matrix-Konto abgemeldet.
Hat mit Abstand den größten Umfang an Features, verglichen mit den meisten Matrix Apps.
Element lacks some customizability but has a lot more functionality than other (more niche) clients. So 5 Stars for being my handy fallback.
summary: Good fallback when using niche client

description: Nombreux problèmes avec Ubuntu - ne s'ouvre plus ; page blanche
summary: Nombreux problèmes avec Ubuntu - ne s'ouvre plus

description: Une erreur inattendue est survenue pendant la résolution de la configuration du serveur d’accueil
невозможно отправить файл в зашифрованные чаты
Невозможно пользоваться. Через минуты две после запуска (а то и раньше) просто крашится. Непонятно, почему.
Старт не удался. Ваш Element неверно настроен.
До сих пор сырой... Но меня чем-то зацепило!
